qas.question: What policy guaranteed that characters have a unique and immutable name?
What happens when a name is defective or misleading?

answers.text: a formal alias may be defined

qas.question: How long has this name immutability been guaranteed?
When an error is found, what is used in place of a formal alias?
When was the formal alias yi created?
What is an example of a symbol that does not use a formal alias?
Which types of characters do not have unique names?

context: All <b7_0>graphic, format, and private use<b7_0/> characters have a unique and immutable name by which they may be identified. This immutability has been guaranteed <a2_0>since <b5_0>Unicode version 2.0<b5_0/><a2_0/> by the <a0_0><b3_0>Name Stability<b3_0/> policy<a0_0/>. In cases where the name is seriously defective and misleading, or has a serious typographical error, <a1_0>a formal alias may be defined<a1_0/>, and applications are encouraged to use the formal alias in place of <b4_0>the official character name<b4_0/>. For example, <b6_0>U+A015 ꀕ YI SYLLABLE WU<b6_0/> has the formal alias yi syllable iteration mark, and U+FE18 ︘ PRESENTATION FORM FOR VERTICAL RIGHT WHITE LENTICULAR BRAKCET (sic) has the formal alias presentation form for vertical right white lenticular bracket.
